entries.content: When leaving a voicemail, clearly state who you are and why you're calling.
Keep voicemail messages concise and to the point.
Mention a specific relevant point in your voicemail, like a previous interaction or shared connection.
Offer a clear call to action in your voicemail, like suggesting a brief chat or sending an email.
Understand that not everyone will respond to your outreach.
Follow up persistently but professionally after leaving a voicemail.
Use email as a follow-up channel after leaving a voicemail.
Reference the voicemail in your follow-up email.
Suggest alternative ways to connect if a phone call isn't convenient.
Be prepared for rejection and don't take it personally.
Have a clear structure or script outline for your calls and voicemails.
Practice your opening lines and value proposition.
Speak clearly and with a confident tone in voicemails.
State your phone number twice slowly in the voicemail.
Leave your name and company name clearly in the voicemail.
The goal of a voicemail is often just to get a callback or pique interest, not to sell the entire product.
Offer a specific reason for calling related to their potential needs or industry trends.
Vary your follow-up messages and channels to avoid sounding repetitive.
End your voicemail with a question that prompts a response, implicitly or explicitly.
"Just following up on the voicemail I left you earlier today regarding..."
entries.notes: Useful phrase for follow-up email after voicemail.
